<h2>Understanding Depression</h2><p>Welc:
Understanding Depression

Welcome! Every action you take here, no matter how small, is a win. This isn’t about doing everything perfectly. It’s about taking the next tiny step, one at a time. And we’re here to cheer you on for each one. Let's get started!
<p>Before we begin, let's take a moment: Before we begin, let's take a moment to check in.
<h2>How have you felt throughout the day: How have you felt throughout the day today?
<p>It’s normal to feel sad or low from t:
It’s normal to feel sad or low from time to time. Losing a job, ending a relationship, the death of a loved one — life events like these can impact your emotional well-being.

But clinical depression is different. It’s a mood disorder that causes continuous feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and loss of interest in daily life. You may also:
Eat or sleep more or less than usual.
<p>But know that it’s not hopeless. Ther: But know that it’s not hopeless. There are many treatments, from lifestyle changes and mindfulness practices to therapy and medication, that can make a big difference.
<p>If you or someone you know is struggl: If you or someone you know is struggling with symptoms that may be related to anxiety, depression, or another mental health condition, contact your health care provider. They can discuss treatment options and work with you to create a care plan that's right for you.
<h2>Know the Risk Factors for Depression:
Know the Risk Factors for Depression

It can be easy to look around (and on your social media feed) and feel like you’re the only one with depression. But you’re far from alone.
<h4>An estimated 5% of adults in the wor: An estimated 5% of adults in the world struggle with depression.
<p>People of all ages, genders, and walk: People of all ages, genders, and walks of life develop clinical depression. Here are some factors that increase the risk:
<p>Dealing with a serious illness like c: Dealing with a serious illness like cancer, heart disease, or chronic pain.
<p>Having a personal or family history o: Having a personal or family history of depression.
<h3>Your First Step: Reflect and Identif:
Your First Step: Reflect and Identify

Let's begin by understanding your experience. Remember the symptoms we talked about on the previous pages?
<p>Eating or sleeping more or less than: Eating or sleeping more or less than usual.
<h3>Today, take these two steps:</h3><ol:
Today, take these two steps:

  1. Jot down (on paper or in an app) any symptoms you recognize from the list above. Bring this to your next visit with a healthcare provider, or save it for your journal. Each symptom you identified is a step toward understanding yourself-not just your depression. 
  2. Think about when your feelings of depression started. What may have triggered them? Knowing this may help you find ways to cope with those feelings and experiences in the future.

<h2>Understand Your Symptoms</h2><p>Scre:
Understand Your Symptoms

Screening for depression is important for early detection and treatment.

A diagnosis can feel overwhelming, but it also provides clarity and direction. Knowing you have depression might make it easier to:
<p>Get support for your unique needs (li: Get support for your unique needs (like therapy or medication).
<p>Understand how depression is affectin: Understand how depression is affecting your life.
<p>Connect with others who may be facing: Connect with others who may be facing similar challenges.
<p>The <b>Patient Health Questionnaire-9: The Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) is a screening test that health care providers use to diagnose depression. You can do it yourself, but it’s recommended to speak with a health care professional about your results to learn more about your mental health, and whether your symptoms reflect depression or something else.
<h2>Take a Short Quiz</h2><p>Let's asses:
Take a Short Quiz

Let's assess your mood using the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9). This tool screens for common depression symptoms.

You'll answer 9 questions based on how often you've been bothered by certain issues over the past two weeks.

Your score range and information to help you understand your results will be provided. This can help you consider next steps.
<p>You can download this assessment to m: You can download this assessment to monitor your symptoms.
<p>The PHQ-9 is an informational screeni: The PHQ-9 is an informational screening tool only. It does not provide a medical diagnosis. Please consult with a healthcare professional for any health concerns.
<h2>During the last two weeks, how often: During the last two weeks, how often have you had little interest or pleasure in doing things?
During the last two weeks, how often have you been feeling down, depressed, or hopeless?
During the last two weeks, how often have you had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much?
During the last two weeks, how often have you felt tired or had little energy?
During the last two weeks, how often have you had a poor appetite or overeaten to the point of discomfort?
During the last two weeks, how often have you felt bad about yourself?
During the last two weeks, how often have you had trouble concentrating on things, like reading, working, or watching television?
During the last two weeks, how often have you moved or spoken so slowly that other people might have noticed? Or have you been more fidgety and restless than usual?
During the last two weeks, how often have you had thoughts about hurting yourself?
<h2>Review your score.&nbsp;</h2><p>Now:
Review your score. 

Now that you’ve taken the quiz, let’s talk about the results. If you tracked your score during the check in, add up the numbers next to all your answers to get your score.

Here’s what different scores may indicate:
<p>Whatever your score, you can take ste: Whatever your score, you can take steps to manage depressive feelings. Knowing where you're at is the first step!

<h2>Minimal Depression</h2><p>With minim:
Minimal Depression

With minimal depression, you may find you can manage symptoms on your own with lifestyle changes, or through talking with a friend or loved one for support.

But there may be times when turning to a friend or loved one isn’t enough. When depression impacts how you think, feel, act, or connect with others, talk therapy can help. 

Mental health support offers you safe, confidential, sensitive, and expert care. It can also be called:
<p>Think of talk therapy as a place wher:
Think of talk therapy as a place where you can share personal experiences in a safe and private space, while finding new ways to feel better.

If you’ve never worked with a therapist before, start with your doctor and ask if they can suggest someone. You can also look for a therapist in your area here.

You can also try out the coping tips in the following activities. Lifestyle changes, such as prioritizing good sleep, exercising regularly, and eating well with a Mediterranean-style diet, may also help you feel better.

Your Next Step

Review your PHQ-9 score. Choose one symptom from the quiz that you want to track more closely this week. Notice how often you experience it and what seems to trigger it. This will help you and your healthcare provider understand your depression better.

<h3>Mild Depression</h3><p>With mild dep:
Mild Depression

With mild depression, you may find you can manage symptoms on your own with lifestyle changes, or through talking with a friend or loved one for support.

But there may be times when turning to a friend or loved one isn’t enough. When depression impacts how you think, feel, act, or connect with others, talk therapy can help. 

Mental health support offers you safe, confidential, sensitive, and expert care. It can also be called:
<h2>Moderate Depression</h2><p>People wh:
Moderate Depression

People who have moderate depression often need additional support to help manage symptoms. This may include psychotherapy (talk therapy), antidepressant medication, or a combination of treatments.

If you’re concerned about your symptoms or would like to better understand the results of the screening test, please reach out for support.

Health professionals and mental health services that can help include:
<p>If you’ve never worked with a therapi:
If you’ve never worked with a therapist before, start with your doctor and ask if they can suggest someone. You can also look for a therapist in your area here.

You can also try out the coping tips in the following activities. Lifestyle changes, such as prioritizing good sleep, exercising regularly, and eating well with a Mediterranean-style diet, may also help you feel better.

If you need immediate help, call the emergency hotline listed above.  

Your Next Step

Review your PHQ-9 score. Choose one symptom from the quiz that you want to track more closely this week. Notice how often you experience it and what seems to trigger it. This will help you and your healthcare provider understand your depression better.

<h2>Severe Depression</h2><p>With severe:
Severe Depression

With severe depression, it’s important to get help right away, especially if you’ve had thoughts of suicide or hurting yourself. Health professionals and mental health services that can help include:
<p>There are many effective depression t:
There are many effective depression treatments that can help you start to feel better, including psychotherapy (talk therapy), antidepressant medication, or a combination of treatments. If you’ve never worked with a therapist before, start with your doctor and ask if they can suggest someone. You can also look for a therapist in your area here.

You can also try out the coping tips in the following activities. Lifestyle changes, such as prioritizing good sleep, exercising regularly, and eating well with a Mediterranean-style diet, may also help you feel better.

If you need immediate help, call the emergency hotline listed above.
